author: @user-fq5ll4bn4u
text: Why this didn't do anything? It just mine mineral  from sc2.bot_ai import BotAI  from sc2.data import Difficulty, Race   from sc2.main import run_game   from sc2.player import Bot, Computer   from sc2 import maps  from sc2.ids.unit_typeid import UnitTypeId  class Ignister(BotAI):  	async def on_step(self, iteration: int): 		print(f"{iteration}") 		 		 		if self.townhalls: 			nexus = self.townhalls.random 			 			if nexus.is_idle and self.can_afford(UnitTypeId.PROBE): 				nexus.train(UnitTypeId.PROBE)   		elif self.structures(UnitTypeId.PYLON) and self.already_pending(UnitTypeId.PYLON) == 0: 			if self.can_afford(UnitTypeId.PYLON): 				await self.build(UnitTypeId.PYLON, near=nexus)                   			 		else: 			if self.can_afford(UnitTypeId.NEXUS): 				await self.expand_now()     run_game( 	maps.get("HardwireLE"), 	[Bot(Race.Protoss, Ignister()), 	 Computer(Race.Zerg, Difficulty.Hard)], 	 realtime=True,

author: @ValkoinenShiro
text: Just writing this and hoping it'll be useful. For the number of workers (probes), usually it's 3 per mineral patch; the number above the nexus (or townhall) can differ per game mode since the optimal "mining" of workers is 2 per patch with the third one mining at a lower rate. In some game modes you can have a lot of bases that can mine and since workers cost supply you may only want 2 per patch so you have enough supply for your army, but if you decide to "tech up" or bank a lot of ressources then going to 3 per patch is not a bad idea.  Getting the maximum amount of workers is called "saturation" and more than 3 workers per ressource does nothing (the gas ressource works the same for the most part, except it's almost always best to put 3 workers since gas is harder to get/has less "patches" to gather from).  Terrans also have mules, a temporary (timed life) mining unit that does not count against that maximum of 3 workers, but that's another thing altogether.
